What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I read a great selection of books from the colonial and post-colonial eras of English literature. The class asked us to reckon with how colonial identities are formed, both by the colonizer and the colonized, and how these identities shape and are shaped by the relationships between them. At its heart, this course is about people and their relationships with other people.
I learned a lot about the history of the British Empire, and I learned a lot about

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I sometimes felt that we did not extract as much from the text as we could have, but that is the curse of the once-a-week seminar. It was helpful to have someone do a mini-presentation every class on that week's book and author.

I really love the no-phones policy, and I think it helped us stay focused and engaged. I also think the books on the syllabus were really well written, and they tied together really well to make an interesting and varied collection of stories and experiences.
It could be improved by giving us shorter novels to read every week along with reviews/critical essays discussing how readers at the time received the work

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, particularly if you have interest in the books on the syllabus. Professor Phillips has so much knowledge on these books and I feel grateful to have had the chance to learn from him.
Yes, this is one of the best classes that I have ever taken at this school. I really enjoyed the books on the syllabus and the way that the class was organized.
Yes! The professor is amazing and class discussions were very engaging

Yes! You read a lot of great books and more generally it's a really rewarding experience to immerse yourself in postcolonial literature and study the effects of Empire through the lens of literature (rather than a traditional history course). Professor Phillips is also a great profhe's funny and full of wisdom and is serious about making sure the conversations we have as a class are intentional.
